Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Carbon Monoxide Dynamics in Geothermal Mats and Earth's Early Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Anaerobic carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation was likely a significant mode of metabolism on the early Earth. Hydrothermal settings today may provide a modern analogue for the study of this ancient microbial energy source and its relation to carbon fluxes on the early Earth. CO is a common trace gas in volcanic emissions and associated hot springs. CO is toxic to numerous microbes because of its strong affinity for the active sites of many metalloenzymes. Nevertheless, several hot spring bacteria have been isolated that are capable of chemolithoautotrophic growth via anaerobic oxidation of CO (CO + H2O = CO2 + H2) in cultures supported by headspace CO partial pressures exceeding 1 atm.
Uzon Caldera and Geyser Valley on the Kamchatka Peninsula in far eastern Siberia are the source regions for several anaerobic carboxydotrophic species. Curiously, the concentrations of CO in the isolation locales are much lower than those in which these carboxydotrophic microbes thrive when cultured. Furthermore, CO consumption rates observed in the anoxic muds of the hot spring outflow channels are far higher than can be supported by the CO supplied by venting reduced waters. These observations imply that in situ production of CO, presumably by other microbes and resulting in locally high CO concentrations, sustains the thriving carboxydotrophic communities. Before the rise of oxygen in the Paleoproterozoic, outgassing of a small portion of this CO produced in anaerobic mats could have been a significant source of CO to the atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit. This study will provide the first detailed field and laboratory examination of CO production and consumption in hot spring sediments. We will target hot springs in Uzon Caldera, Kamchatka, and analogous springs in Devil?s Kitchen, Lassen Volcanic National Park, California. Fine scale chemical gradients in spring sediments will be assessed using scanning voltammetry microelectrodes. CO consumption rates and products will be determined by in situ 14CO tracer incubations. Couplings between CO cycling and various metabolic modes (i.e., sulfate, FeIII, and MnIV reduction as inferred in the field from microelectrode profiles) will be tested using redox-gradient reactors in the lab. Cryosections of sediment mini-cores will be used for DNA extraction to profile microbial communities in these redox gradients. We will also make preliminary assessments of CO exchange with the atmosphere through measuring CO concentrations in vadose zone gases in relation to dissolved concentrations in the underlying saturated zone. As a result, this work will improve our understanding of the role that carboxydotrophy may have played as a standalone metabolism and as a means of mediating CO fluxes to and from the atmosphere on the early Earth.

This work will also pioneer the use of fluorescent reporters in genetically engineered thermophiles as an analytical tool for laboratory microcosm experiments. Localized hot spots of CO production are not resolvable using current methods. The carboxydotrophs with recombinant fluorescent reporters will serve as visual indicators of zones with high dissolved CO concentrations, and will demonstrate more broadly the utility of biosensors in geochemistry.

Broader Impacts. This proposal provides partial support for one graduate student at University of Chicago and one at U. Maryland Biotechnology Inst., with additional travel and logistical support for a summer undergraduate intern at U. Chicago to participate in both field seasons. This work will extend our existing international collaboration with members of the Kamchatka Institute of Volcanology and Seismology and the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow. Finally, the proposed research will be shared with the general public through the extension of a nationally recognized public outreach collaboration on Kamchatka extremophiles with the San Francisco Exploratorium. A web exhibit will be developed in both English and Russian to describe the research approach and major findings from this biogeochemistry study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the role that carbon monoxide plays in structuring microbial ecosystems in hot springs.  We also examined whether or not carbon monoxide was produced within these ecosystems. Finally, we explored the extent to which microbial carbon monoxide production could have had an important influence on the chemistry of Earth's atmosphere some 2.5 billion years ago and earlier, before there was substantial oxygen in the atmosphere.

This study was rooted in field campaigns to study the coupling between chemistry and microbiology of hot springs.  In 2009, we studied the springs in Lassen Volcanic National Park, CA, USA. In 2010, we initiated an international collaboration with Russian scientists to study springs in Uzon Caldera, Kamchatka, Russia (see first image).  Both campaigns were successful. We measured the chemistry and temperature of hot springs in the field. We collected samples for analysis of gases (both those bubbling up in the springs and those dissolved in the spring waters) and for studying the microbial inhabitants of these springs (2nd through 4th images). We also cultivated in the laboratory bacteria and archaea that have been isolated from these or similar springs in order to better understand the ways in which these microbes respond to carbon monoxide.

The intellectual merit and impact of this work centers on the following findings:

a) Nearly all of the hot springs we studied had more dissolved carbon monoxide than could be explained by equilibrium with the volcanic gases bubbling up in the springs (3rd - 4th images).  This indicates that there is a near surface source of carbon monoxide, which appears to be microbial.

b) The hot spring microbial communities have diverse biochemical sensing mechanisms for determining approximate CO concentrations and regulating their own metabolism in response. These sensing mechanisms are encoded by genes that have been horizontally transferred among and across broad lineages of bacteria and archaea. This suggests widespread adaptation of anaerobic bacteria and archaea to the presence of carbon monoxide (2nd image).

c) The levels of carbon monoxide supported by these anaerobic microbial communities are high. If they are generalizable to aquatic anaerobic environments, then on the early Earth atmospheric carbon monoxide concentrations could have easily reached 1-5%. Such levels would have been high enough to play a significant role in structuring primitive microbial ecosystems.

These results have been published in three papers and presented in over 15 talks and posters at national and international meetings.  Two more significant papers have been drafted and will be submitted for publication shortly.

The broader impacts of this work center initially on training of the next generation of scientific and technical leaders in this country, fostering scientific collaboration between the US and Russia, and inspiring younger students (in grades K-12) by connecting their grade school science curriculum to cutting edge scientific research and discovery.

Specifically, this grant funded the PhD work of two students. One has gone on to become a professor at a research university. The other is working in a technical capacity on contracts for a major US corporation. This work also supported summer research and participation in field work by an undergraduate who has since gone on to work on the intersection of science and public policy.

We conducted a successful week-long field season in Kamchatka in partnership with collaborators from the Winogradsky Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow.  In addition to the resultant field and laboratory research highlighted above, this field season provided the opportunity to host an international conference on extremophiles in a setting that permitted helicopter-based field trips to remote hot springs. The conference was conducted in Petropavlovsk, Russia, in August 2010, with support from NSF, NASA, and the biotechnology industry.  Senior scientists, postdoctoral research fellows, and PhD students from the US, Europe, South America, and Asia attended.

We have also developed lectures and hands-on activities to bring to life for K-12 students the process of scientific discovery related to hot springs and volcanoes.  We have introduced numerous students in both Illinois and Maryland to these exciting lessons and activities (5th image).
